description:
Many of the Mag7 stocks have a boat load of cash, billions of dollars of cash ready to be deployed.

However, Warren Buffett & Co over at $BRK.B have even more with nearly $190 Billion in cash. Berkshire does not pay a dividend but it buys back stock aggressively. 

In the meantime, are they waiting for an opportunity to acquire a company? We will have to see.

description:
Warren Buffett is known as being the GOAT of investing.

He has shown the importance of diversification, but more importantly the importance of PATIENCE. Doing your due diligence to determine whether a stock is OVERvalued or UNDERvalued is so important.

Wait to buy at a price you are comfortable buying at, do not chase stocks at bad valuations.

Do you invest based on Fundamentals. If you are interested in learning more, consider working with me 1 on 1 for my 6-week Investing Accelerator course. Go to https://go.roussinfinancial.com/evaluation

latest_comments.comments: "Be fearful when others are greedy, and be greedy when others are fearful." It suggests buying stocks when prices are low (during fear) and avoiding them when prices are high (during hype). However, timing the market is difficult, making it challenging to predict exactly when the market is at its lowest or highest points. This can lead to missed opportunities if investors wait for the perfect moment to buy. Additionally, Warren Buffett himself advocates for long-term investing in fundamentally strong companies, and trying to buy only during market lows can result in missed long-term growth opportunities. Market conditions, company performance, and global events can impact stock prices unpredictably, making a rigid buy-low strategy potentially unfeasible. Furthermore, relying on a single strategy ignores the importance of diversification in managing risks and providing stability and growth. Thus, while buying during market lows and selling during highs seems logical, it oversimplifies the complexities of investing, and a balanced, long-term approach with diversification often yields better results.

How is MO not in here…

This image depicts a "Stairway to Dividends," suggesting that certain companies provide more stability, while others offer more dividend growth. Here's a simple refutation:
The image implies that companies at the bottom of the stairway, like Johnson & Johnson and Waste Management, provide more stability but less dividend growth, while companies at the top, like Zoetis and Starbucks, offer more dividend growth but less stability.
However, the relationship between stability and dividend growth is not always linear. Some companies can offer both high stability and significant dividend growth simultaneously. For instance, Microsoft, shown in the middle tier, has historically demonstrated strong stability and impressive dividend growth.
Additionally, market conditions, management decisions, and industry factors can influence both stability and dividend growth, making it overly simplistic to categorize companies strictly based on these criteria.
In summary, while the image presents a clear visual categorization, real-world dynamics are more complex, and individual company performance can defy these generalized tiers.

description:

description:
When it comes to investing, I tend to focus on quality first and foremost. One of the most important things I focus on when analyzing a company is how efficient the company is ran. How strong on their profit margins?

Companies that are efficient and have higher profit margins tend to generate more cash and companies with more cash have the ability to pay a dividend consistently and grow that dividend. 

In this image, you will see these companies profit margins along with their five-year dividend growth rate.

How many companies on this list do you own?
